text: A die is thrown 6 times. If 'getting an odd number' is a success, find the probability of (i) 5 successes (ii) at least 5 successes (iii) at most 5 successes. (HSC Textbook)
answer:
This is a binomial distribution with $n=6$. The probability of success (odd number) is $p = 3/6 = 1/2$, so $q=1/2$. The formula is $P(X=k) = \binom{n}{k}p^k q^{n-k}$.
i) $P(X=5) = \binom{6}{5}(\frac{1}{2})^5(\frac{1}{2})^1 = 6 \cdot \frac{1}{64} = \frac{6}{64} = \frac{3}{32}$.
ii) $P(X \ge 5) = P(X=5)+P(X=6)$.
$P(X=6) = \binom{6}{6}(\frac{1}{2})^6 = \frac{1}{64}$.
$P(X \ge 5) = \frac{6}{64} + \frac{1}{64} = \frac{7}{64}$.
iii) $P(X \le 5) = 1-P(X > 5) = 1-P(X=6) = 1 - \frac{1}{64} = \frac{63}{64}$.

text: A pair of dice is thrown 4 times. If getting a doublet is considered a success, find the probability of two successes. (March 2022)
answer:
The probability of getting a doublet is $p = 6/36 = 1/6$. The number of trials is $n=4$. This is a binomial distribution problem. The probability of failure is $q = 1-p = 5/6$.
We want the probability of two successes, $P(X=2)$.
$P(X=2) = \binom{4}{2}(\frac{1}{6})^2(\frac{5}{6})^{2} = 6 \cdot \frac{1}{36} \cdot \frac{25}{36} = \frac{150}{1296} = \frac{25}{216}$.

text: There are 5% defective items in a large bulk of items. What is the probability that a sample of 10 items will include not more than one defective item?
answer:
This is a binomial distribution with $n=10$. The probability of a defective item is $p = 0.05$. The probability of a non-defective item is $q = 0.95$.
We want $P(X \le 1) = P(X=0)+P(X=1)$.
$P(X=0) = \binom{10}{0}(0.05)^0(0.95)^{10} = (0.95)^{10} \approx 0.5987$.
$P(X=1) = \binom{10}{1}(0.05)^1(0.95)^9 = 10(0.05)(0.95)^9 \approx 0.3151$.
$P(X \le 1) \approx 0.5987 + 0.3151 = 0.9138$.

text: Five cards are drawn successively with replacement from a well-shuffled deck of 52 cards, find the probability that (i) all the five cards are spades (ii) only 3 cards are spades (iii) none is a spade.
answer:
This is a binomial distribution with $n=5$. The probability of a spade is $p = 13/52 = 1/4$, so $q=3/4$.
i) $P(X=5) = \binom{5}{5}(\frac{1}{4})^5(\frac{3}{4})^0 = \frac{1}{1024}$.
ii) $P(X=3) = \binom{5}{3}(\frac{1}{4})^3(\frac{3}{4})^2 = 10 \cdot \frac{1}{64} \cdot \frac{9}{16} = \frac{90}{1024} = \frac{45}{512}$.
iii) $P(X=0) = \binom{5}{0}(\frac{1}{4})^0(\frac{3}{4})^5 = \frac{243}{1024}$.

text: The probability that a bulb produced by a factory will fuse after 150 days of use is 0.05. Find the probability that out of 5 such bulbs (i) none (ii) not more than one (iii) more than one (iv) at least one will fuse after 150 days of use.
A bag consists of 10 balls each marked with one of the digits 0 to 9. If four balls are drawn successively with replacement from the bag, what is the probability that none is marked with the digit 0?
answer:
This is a binomial distribution with $n=4$. The probability of drawing a '0' is $p = 1/10$. The probability of not drawing a '0' is $q = 9/10$. We want $P(X=0)$, where X is the number of '0's drawn.
$P(X=0) = \binom{4}{0}(1/10)^0(9/10)^4 = (0.9)^4 = 0.6561$.

text: On a multiple choice examination with three possible answers for each of the five questions, what is the probability that a candidate would get four or more correct answers just by guessing?
answer:
This is a binomial distribution with $n=5$. The probability of guessing correctly is $p = 1/3$, so $q=2/3$. We want $P(X \ge 4) = P(X=4)+P(X=5)$.
$P(X=4) = \binom{5}{4}(\frac{1}{3})^4(\frac{2}{3})^1 = 5 \cdot \frac{2}{243} = \frac{10}{243}$.
$P(X=5) = \binom{5}{5}(\frac{1}{3})^5(\frac{2}{3})^0 = \frac{1}{243}$.
$P(X \ge 4) = \frac{10}{243} + \frac{1}{243} = \frac{11}{243}$.

text: If a fair coin is tossed 10 times find the probability that it shows heads (i) 5 times (ii) in the first four tosses and tail in last six tosses.
answer:
This is a binomial distribution with $n=10$ and $p=1/2$.
i) $P(X=5) = \binom{10}{5}(\frac{1}{2})^{10} = 252 \times \frac{1}{1024} = \frac{63}{256}$.
ii) This is a specific sequence. The probability is $P(HHHH TTTTTT) = (\frac{1}{2})^4 (\frac{1}{2})^6 = (\frac{1}{2})^{10} = \frac{1}{1024}$.

text: Probability that bomb will hit target is 0.8. Find the probability that out of 10 bombs dropped exactly 2 will miss the target.
answer:
This is a binomial distribution with $n=10$. Let 'missing' be a success. So $p=0.2, q=0.8$. We want $P(X=2)$.
$P(X=2) = \binom{10}{2}(0.2)^2(0.8)^{8} = 45(0.04)(0.16777) \approx 0.3020$.

The probability that a lamp in a classroom will be burnt out is 0.3. Six lamps are fitted in the classroom. If the classroom is unusable if the number of lamps burning is less than four, find the probability that the classroom cannot be used.
answer:
Let 'not burnt out' be success. So $p=0.7, q=0.3, n=6$. The classroom is unusable if the number of successes (burning lamps) is less than 4, i.e., $X \in \{0,1,2,3\}$.
$P(X < 4) = P(0)+P(1)+P(2)+P(3)$.
$P(X=0) = (0.3)^6 \approx 0.0007$.
$P(X=1) = \binom{6}{1}(0.7)^1(0.3)^5 \approx 0.0102$.
$P(X=2) = \binom{6}{2}(0.7)^2(0.3)^4 \approx 0.0595$.
$P(X=3) = \binom{6}{3}(0.7)^3(0.3)^3 \approx 0.1852$.
$P(X < 4) \approx 0.0007+0.0102+0.0595+0.1852 = 0.2556$.

text: A lot of 100 items contains 10 defective items. Five items are selected at random from the lot and sent to the retail store. What is the probability that the store will receive at most one defective item?
answer:
This is a **hypergeometric distribution** problem ($N=100, K=10, n=5$). We want $P(X \le 1) = P(X=0)+P(X=1)$.
$P(X=0) = \frac{\binom{10}{0}\binom{90}{5}}{\binom{100}{5}} \approx 0.5838$.
$P(X=1) = \frac{\binom{10}{1}\binom{90}{4}}{\binom{100}{5}} \approx 0.3394$.
$P(X \le 1) \approx 0.5838+0.3394 = 0.9232$.

The probability that a certain kind of component will survive a check test is 0.6. Find the probability that exactly 2 of the next 4 components tested survive.
answer:
This is a binomial distribution with $n=4, p=0.6$. We want $P(X=2)$.
$P(X=2) = \binom{4}{2}(0.6)^2(0.4)^2 = 6(0.36)(0.16) = 0.3456$.

The probability that a machine develops a fault within the first 3 years of use is 0.003. If 40 machines are selected at random, calculate the probability that 38 or more will not develop any faults.
answer:
Let 'not developing a fault' be a success. So $p=0.997, n=40$. We want $P(X \ge 38) = P(38)+P(39)+P(40)$.
$P(X=38) = \binom{40}{38}(0.997)^{38}(0.003)^2 \approx 0.0062$.
$P(X=39) = \binom{40}{39}(0.997)^{39}(0.003)^1 \approx 0.1072$.
$P(X=40) = (0.997)^{40} \approx 0.8868$.
$P(X \ge 38) \approx 0.0062+0.1072+0.8868 = 1.0002$. Due to rounding, the sum is slightly off. A more precise calculation yields approximately 0.9998.

answer:
The probability of rain is $p=12/30=0.4$. This is a binomial distribution with $n=7$.
$P(X=3) = \binom{7}{3}(0.4)^3(0.6)^4 = 35(0.064)(0.1296) \approx 0.2903$.

text: How many trials are required in a binomial distribution with $p=0.01$ to have a probability greater than 0.5 of getting at least one success?
answer:
We want to find $n$ such that $P(X \ge 1) > 0.5$.
$1-P(X=0) > 0.5 \implies 1-(0.99)^n > 0.5 \implies 0.5 > (0.99)^n$.
Taking logs: $\ln(0.5) > n\ln(0.99) \implies n > \frac{\ln(0.5)}{\ln(0.99)} \approx 68.9$.
So, a minimum of 69 trials are required.

text: In a binomial distribution with five Bernoulli's trials, the probability of one and two successes are 0.4096 and 0.2048 respectively. Find the probability of success.
answer:
$P(X=1) = 5pq^4 = 0.4096$.
$P(X=2) = 10p^2q^3 = 0.2048$.
Dividing the second by the first: $\frac{10p^2q^3}{5pq^4} = \frac{0.2048}{0.4096} = 0.5$.
$\frac{2p}{q} = 0.5 \implies 2p = 0.5(1-p) \implies 2.5p=0.5 \implies p=0.2$.
